pros: Fellow RN's are hard-working, efficient and true team players

And now, new grads are being hired directly into critical care areas with only a short critical practice orientation....unsafe practice!!!

review_title: Rehab therapist, good pension, long hours
pros: Great pension, possibility for flexible hours and lots of days off work, fulfilling to work with patients in hard situations.
cons: Long 12 hour shifts make doing things outside of work on your work days challenging, but great since you have more full days off work. Management and sometimes coworkers not always open to implementing change. Not many options for modified/flexible style work. Unionized so there is no flexibility in pay increases unless upon hiring you have prior work experience to move up the existing pay scale one time. Have to pay into health benefits. No room for lateral or vertical movement career-wise as a rehabilitation therapist

job_title: Public Relations Specialist in Hamilton, ON
pros: Good salary, pension, benefits. Nice corporate office (if you ignore Jackson square downstairs). Pretty good hours and respectable work/life balance.
cons:
Very bureaucratic and slow-moving. Silo’d to a point of inefficiency - battles between departments, little to no sharing of information. Workplace culture can be toxic, cliquey. Many employees who do very little get rewarded or at least get to coast with their cushy jobs. Too many meetings, not a lot of actual work getting accomplished. New ideas/people get stifled in favour of old processes, procedures. And not many opportunities for advancement or growth (just do-your-job mentality). Favouritism is commonplace. 
Also, HR is pretty much useless in terms of any employee support. There’s a different “partner” every few months and they basically tell you to talk to your manager if you have any issues. Speaking of which, they put too much power in hands of individual managers. There should be more organizational consensus and cohesiveness.
Also new hires are typically contract so they don’t have to pay pension or benefits.

job_title: Business Clerk Engineering Chedoke in Hamilton, ON
pros: Working to make the patients stay the best experience possible was always my main goal and going above and beyond to achieve that.  Doing this for 35 years was a pleasure and an undertaking at times.  Making sure that the staff were paid properly and in a timely manor in the department that i was in was my goal.  Helping the other departments from around the hospital that called into our  engineering department was something i enjoyed doing.  if i didn't know the answer i called around to find out and then returned the call.  It was very gratifying.   i loved my job and miss feeling the achievement that i had.
cons: Working in a department that  was in turmoil was difficult to handle.  Even though managers were  replaced it is hard to work when the abuse and harassment polices are not adhered too.  Moving poor management from site to site instead of removing them from the system only frustrates and degrades staff moral.

review_title: Periop used to be a great place, not so much anymore
pros: Can be a very exciting place to work, tons of learning opportunities, generally decent front line staff, comparable wages to other hospitals
cons: Devaluing of staff, we are treated as nothing more than a warm body to fill a position. Paychecks are often wrong, schedule is often wrong, not paid for overtime...have to fight for it, frequent forced overtime, say they support education but that is true only if it does not inconvenience them in any wayvsuch as requiring a day or part of a day off. Vacations are not approved until the day before it is to start so don't go planning a trip anytime soon.  You won't know if you can go until the day before your plane leaves.

review_title: Cushy job if that's what you want
pros: HHS is an excellent employer. They're focused on keeping employees happy. They're a public organization, which means the pace isn't too quick if that's what you want. It's easy to maintain a good work/life balance. Compensation is very high relative to the skills required to fill the positions. You can land a gig and wait out your 30 years for retirement.
cons: They're a public organization, which means the pace is slow. There isn't much initiative to drive change, which can be very frustrating if you're looking to improve things. Management isn't very results-oriented and seniority has a bit too much weight in the organization. There are opportunities for advancement, but it takes a long time to achieve them regardless of the success you have in your position.

pros: The JCC’s trials department is overall an amazing group of individuals. For the most part team oriented and welcoming group. Good stepping stone for gaining clinical research experience.
cons: The position is unionized and the majority of the individuals in the department are very senior members of the union. Therefore, there is zero possibility of obtaining promotions etc., for young driven individuals because the union. This ends up hindering the department since there’s no possibility of innovation or growth. Some doctors have a major chip on their shoulder and make it seem like they’re doing you some huge favour or that your trial is a nuisance to them, despite them agreeing to be sub-I’s for a study.

job_title: Registered Practical Nurse in Hamilton, ON
pros: Many resources, many opportunities for learning as well as employee benefits, employee discounts and vacation bonuses. Nursing orientation is a nice review before practicing on a ward as you highlight some common elements such as airway disorders and diabetes.
cons: There is not much opportunity for RPNs to grow in the company other than standard ward positions. Regular part-time employees are often working regular full time hours without the benefits.

pros: great salary and excellent benefits; if you're lucky you may land a good team and a solid manager.
cons: roles and responsibilities are  inconsistent (within departments and individual teams). Some people seem to do nothing all day, every day, while others work like crazy and carry the load -- what's worse, management consistently awards those who do nothing. Its shocking how embedded this practice is. At the end of the day, everyone overlooks the obvious and focuses on covering their own butt and getting their paycheck.

pros: reasonable benefits and pay for full time workers,
cons:
Hard to get full time position. Be prepared to work short staffed 50-80% of your shifts. 
Corporate initiatives and changes without real input from staff.

Some excellent people with great talent to work with.

cons:
Stifling bureaucracy for moving things forward.
IT services/helpdesk would fail in a real business world model.  
Too many silos despite leadership direction to do otherwise.
Turf and long term people in roles, who won't be removed, are a chronic problem.

review_title: Experience varies widely based on department
pros: Great colleagues & team in some departments, my direct supervisor was amazing, opportunities for continued learning/rounds, strong pay, access to resources
cons: Everyone is a bit hurried & overworked, needs better work/life balance, management & staff seemed to be on very different pages in some departments

review_title: Customer care Centre a Great place to work except for the older unionized employees
pros:
Overall, great people, good at their job, talented, caring concerned.
Great managers, specifically in the Customer Care centre
Good pay, physical job, happy social environment amongst employees.
cons:
All over the map hours. you can work overnight, then get called in after 3 hours sleep.
The older unionized employees are problematic, some, not all are quite lazy and ambivalent.

pros: Nice environment physically to work in.  Benefits are good, great people in the hospital to work with.  If you want to work in research go to McMaster.
cons: Everything else.  The pay is low, the Managers get NO training on how to deal with people on any level, favoritism is rampant,   Mistakes are swept under the rug...dangerous.  Overall I would not recommend research at all.  Go to McMaster.

pros: Part of a union so it's great for job security.  Pays fairly well, but could always use a little more.  Great medical benefits, paid vacation and paid sick time.
cons: Because of the union, you can never ask for a raise.  You get the same money as everyone else with your job description, even if you do a lot better work than they do.

pros: Laugh out loud... Not much...
cons:
I work here. I used to love my job.

The CEO and any upper management literally do not care about frontline staff. You can work tirelessly each day, non-stop for the 12 hour tours, taking care of the sick and powerless who need you, be their advocate and  then be ripped apart if you get burned out or sick... 

You only get 5 sick days a year.——When frontline staff work with infectious and contaminated environments and the extremely ill? Not appropriate at all.

Those who stand up for their own rights (like when a patient assaults them), or those who speak out, are belittled, or the issue is degraded to insignificance. I go home with bruises daily. 

The supplies we are provided to give care to the patients gets cheaper each month—sometimes supplies are non existent at smaller sites, so they have to improvise...

No one listens to the front line staff. Even nurses are kept out of safety huddles and patient discussions with the interdisciplinary team (when we spend all of our time with them) because it’s scheduled at a time that is inappropriate for us.

There was a fire at one of the smaller hospitals that is, and it was handled amazingly and professionally by the staff. Not a single patient was hurt—staff were though, they ended up on modified duties or off work for the strength they had that day—but occupational health “encouraged” them back to their full work duties at an expedited pace.. There were also no call-outs to bring outside staff in to assist (as per protocol), there was no guiding manager or administrator (since it was a weekend, and that “small site” doesn’t receive enough funding to even have a manager, facility maintenance, or even clerks on weekends). The one on call was literally clueless about the site.
Everyone was exposed to asbestos smoke and debris since there were no maintenance employees on site to shut the vents off to the units and patients rooms; there were no available (vital) medications near the areas that patients were moved to (but thankfully the palliative doctor and nurses risked themselves and brought some down); and the nurses from each floor jumped in to still provide care to patients in need when the south side of the building was still smoking and ablaze. AND while this was happening, a code orange was called at other hospitals, but never declared or mentioned to staff evolved. 

More credit should be given to the staff of that hospital.

It was an unorganized disaster, with NO leadership, handled beautifully by the staff. They deserve more credit.
OH, and there was no mention of the cause of the fire? Just that they want to give up on the entire building. And move all programs somewhere else.




If you work here, just recognize you are just a number to them... it’s the same anywhere, but the talents of the nurses and allied staff are lost and unacknowledged. Most young staff leave promptly due to this. But when you’ve been working somewhere for a decade or two, it’s hard to leave such an amazing team, who feel just like me—even when it’s heartbreaking and there’s no respect or appreciation given from anyone above.

review_title: Great company to work for! The only reason I left is to pursue a full-time position.
pros: Work-life balance, vacation/lieu time, co-workers are all great, happy, very welcoming. Opportunities to move around within the organization, management is very appreciative! I always felt valued at HHS.
cons: Union contracts make it hard to progress (seniority rules rather than experience), hard to move into full-time positions because of this.
